text.0: neer doth the man repent who seeking profit bringeth his gift to the farstriding viṣṇu.
text.1: he who adoreth him with all his spirit winneth himself so great a benefactor.
text.2: thou viṣṇu constant in thy courses gavest goodwill to all men and a hymn that lasteth.
text.3: that thou mightst move us to abundant comfort of very splendid wealth with store of horses.
text.4: three times strode forth this god in all his grandeur over this earth bright with a hundred splendours.
text.5: foremost be viṣṇu stronger than the strongest for glorious is his name who lives for ever.
text.6: over this earth with mighty step strode viṣṇu ready to give it for a home to manu.
text.7: in him the humble people trust for safety he nobly born hath made them spacious dwellings.
text.8: today i laud this name o gipivista i skilled in rules the name of thee the noble.
text.9: yea i the poor and weak praise thee the mighty who dwellest in the realm beyond this region.
text.10: what was there to be blamed in thee o viṣṇu when thou declaredst i am sipivista.
text.11: hide not this form from us nor keep it secret since thou didst wear another shape in battle.
text.12: o viṣṇu unto thee my lips cry vaṣaṭ let this mine offering sipivista please thee.
text.13: may these my songs of eulogy exalt thee preserve us evermore ye gods with blessings.
